image.altText: A middle aged man with short greying hair stands in front of a backdrop displaying the Australian Parliament House flagpole.

items.synopsis: The treasurer admits that Australia is on track to fall short of its climate targets without more money invested, quicker construction of renewables projects, and better regulation.

title.children: Treasurer Jim Chalmers concedes Australia risks missing its climate targets

image.altText: A man and three women posing with their awards in front of an oval

items.synopsis: Environmental scientist and activist Timothy Jarvis says he hopes his new title as South Australia's 2024 Australian of the Year would inspire people to help stop climate change in any way they can.

title.children: 'Up to each of us to make a difference': SA Australian of the Year announced

image.altText: Two men stand side by side leaning on the front of a small plane on a runway.

items.synopsis: It took two years and an unconventional job package, including pilot training, but this outback town once again has a doctor on duty.

title.children: Global recruitment drive lands a much-needed GP for outback SA town Wudinna

image.altText: A small brown brick house

items.synopsis: A government-owned house that has been empty for seven years in the small town of Kalangadoo will be offered to other public servants and the town's police station will close.

title.children: Housing crisis sparks action to rent out long-vacant house reserved for police

image.altText: A woman cries in front of a car.

items.synopsis: Police have escorted the woman to a local police station following a search of her property. She cooked a mushroom lunch suspected of killing three people in Victoria's east.

title.children: Erin Patterson escorted to police station for interview after investigators search her home

image.altText: Abdullah, pictured with his grandkids.

items.synopsis: Twenty Australians have successfully fled Gaza as 65 remain registered to leave, according to foreign affairs officials.

title.children: 'You can go, she has to stay': Australian man returns to Gaza after wife denied border crossing

image.altText: A pair of regent parrots on a stick with slightly different colouring.

items.synopsis: The regent parrot population is suffering, but a group of researchers who specialise in working out what's wrong with rare and beautiful creatures could make the difference.

title.children: This beloved parrot is in decline in SA's Riverland. Enter the 'difficult-bird' research team

image.altText: A man crouches on a hospital floor looking at people under silver blankets

items.synopsis: In Gaza's busiest hospital, doctors do what they can to treat a tidal wave of desperate patients injured in Israeli air strikes. WARNING: Some readers might find the details and images in this story distressing.

title.children: Sewing needles, dishwashing liquid and kids on the floor: The unthinkable horrors of Gaza's hospitals

image.altText: A man dressed as Santa wearing a face mask.

items.synopsis: The Director of Communicable Diseases at NSW Health has warned a COVID wave could peak at Christmas for the third year in a row.

title.children: Another 'COVID Christmas' on the cards thanks to fresh wave, experts warn

image.altText: Ian Smith (1)

items.synopsis: For years, sperm donors believed their identity would remain secret, but the explosion of online DNA databases changed everything, writes Ian Smith.

title.children: I was meant to be anonymous to my seven biological kids — but that's impossible today

image.altText: man in suit rubbing hands together next to logo of a white x on black background

items.synopsis: In the year since Elon Musk took over Twitter, the platform now known as X, has reportedly halved in value, and is considered "no longer safe" for users in countries where freedom of expression has increasingly come under threat.

title.children: 'Let that sink in!': Musk's words come back to bite as X looks like it has become 'worthless'

image.altText: entrance to shopping stor with Kmart signage and customers walking and with trolleys by customer service desk

items.synopsis: Australian retailer Kmart has paid a $1.3 million fine for having sent more than 200,000 marketing emails to people who had already unsubscribed.

title.children: Kmart slapped with $1.3 million fine for sending marketing emails to customers who opted out

image.altText: A man in a suit and tie sits at a desk near the front of a courtroom. Other people are behind him in rows of seats.

items.synopsis: The former US president's eldest son testifies in court, ahead of more family appearances in the coming days.

title.children: What you need to know about Donald Trump Jr's testimony in the trial which threatens his father's real estate empire

image.altText: A flare can be seen over a building.

items.synopsis: A director for Human Rights Watch says the blocking of aid, including food, water and medicine, amounts to collective punishment of civilians, which could amount to a war crime.

title.children: Human Rights Watch says blocking aid to Gaza, Israeli strikes could amount to war crimes

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Foreign Minister Penny Wong has reiterated a call for a "humanitarian pause" to deliver supplies to people in Gaza. "I again reiterate, Australia's call for humanitarian pauses on hostilities. We want humanitarian supplies of food, water, medicine, fuel to reach people in desperate need," she told reporters in Adelaide. Ms Wong said that while Israel has a right to defend itself, it also has an obligation to follow international law. "I've said that, in affirming our view, that Israel has a right to defend itself, Israel's friends including Australia have emphasised that the way Israel does that matters," she said. "We know that Hamas is a terrorist group, we know that it has burrowed itself into civilian infrastructure, we know that it's using civilians as a shield. We know that terrorism must be confronted. "All of these challenges do not lessen Israel's obligation to observe international law and the rules of war. Even in war, there are rules. "The international community will not accept ongoing civilian deaths."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Wong calls for 'humanitarian pause', says Israel must follow 'rules of war'

children.content: Foreign Minister Penny Wong

children.content: "I again reiterate, Australia's call for humanitarian pauses on hostilities. We want humanitarian supplies of food, water, medicine, fuel to reach people in desperate need," she told reporters in Adelaide.
Ms Wong said that while Israel has a right to defend itself, it also has an obligation to follow international law.
"I've said that, in affirming our view, that Israel has a right to defend itself, Israel's friends including Australia have emphasised that the way Israel does that matters," she said.
"We know that Hamas is a terrorist group, we know that it has burrowed itself into civilian infrastructure, we know that it's using civilians as a shield. We know that terrorism must be confronted.
"All of these challenges do not lessen Israel's obligation to observe international law and the rules of war. Even in war, there are rules.
"The international community will not accept ongoing civilian deaths."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: When asked about retired public school teacher Abdullah Dahlan, one of the Australians still stuck in Gaza, she said the Australian government is doing all they can to get remaining Australians and visa holders out. Mr Dahlan said he went to the border crossing but decided to go back into Gaza when Egyptian officials wouldn't let his wife Samah, a Palestinian with a visa for Australia, leave. "There are a lot more nationals to get out... we hope that the parties who have brokered this arrangement can continue to assure passage for civilians out of Gaza. [We] will continue to do what we can to press for that, obviously, as I said, the numbers are substantial but I can assure Australians and all of the Australians who worried about those relatives, friends in Gaza that we will continue to press for Australians to have safe passage," she says. "I assume he is registered with us and we are in contact with, as much as we are able to." "Communications have been disrupted at times and difficult circumstances but we are in contact with all the Australians who are registered and we are seeking to assist all of those who wish to leave."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Efforts underway to get remaining Australians out says Wong

children.content: When asked about retired public school teacher Abdullah Dahlan,
one of the Australians still stuck in Gaza
, she said the Australian government is doing all they can to get remaining Australians and visa holders out.
Mr Dahlan said he went to the border crossing but decided to go back into Gaza when Egyptian officials wouldn't let his wife Samah, a Palestinian with a visa for Australia, leave.
"There are a lot more nationals to get out... we hope that the parties who have brokered this arrangement can continue to assure passage for civilians out of Gaza. [We]

will continue to do what we can to press for that, obviously, as I said, the numbers are substantial but I can assure Australians and all of the Australians who worried about those relatives, friends in Gaza that we will continue to press for Australians to have safe passage," she says.
"I assume he is registered with us and we are in contact with, as much as we are able to."

"Communications have been disrupted at times and difficult circumstances but we are in contact with all the Australians who are registered and we are seeking to assist all of those who wish to leave."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Minister for Foreign Affairs Penny Wong has just spoken to reporters in Adelaide about the situation in Gaza and the Australians who are wanting to return home. Ms Wong said she has spoken with the Australian ambassador to Cairo who confirmed that the Australians who have made it there are in good health. "I'm so relieved and grateful this cohort was able to cross. They have been supported by a staff in Egypt, transborder to Cairo and travel arrangements are being made for them to get home free of charge," she said. The ambassador confirmed there were children among the cohort of people who left Gaza among some of the first foreign nationals to cross the border through Rafah. "I could hear children in the background and I said to him, are there kids? And he said yes, some of the Australian children who made it to Cairo today," Ms Wong said. "They had a seven journey which is pretty tiring. I asked about the health of all the Australians, he said that people seemed in good health and were relieved but we are insuring anyone who needs medical attention will receive it. " Ms Wong thanked DFAT staff and other Australian agencies for their work in Canberra and on the ground in Egypt and Israel in contributing to the outcome. She also thanked her counterparts in Egypt, Qatar Israel and the US for brokering the arrangement. The work continues to bring the remaining Australians, perfmanent residents and their families home, she said. "I know how distressing the situation is for them and for their next of kin. Please be sure, we will continue to press for all of you to cross the border in Gaza, we will continue to do what we've been doing for the last few weeks which is to engage with all that we can to ensure safe passage."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australians who left Gaza are in good health: Penny Wong

The ambassador confirmed there were children among the cohort of people who left Gaza among some of the first foreign nationals to cross the border through Rafah.
"I could hear children in the background and I said to him, are there kids? And he said yes, some of the Australian children who made it to Cairo today," Ms Wong said.

"They had a seven journey which is pretty tiring. I asked about the health of all the Australians, he said that people seemed in good health and were relieved but we are insuring anyone who needs medical attention will receive it. "
Ms Wong thanked DFAT staff and other Australian agencies for their work in Canberra and on the ground in Egypt and Israel in contributing to the outcome.
She also thanked her counterparts in Egypt, Qatar Israel and the US for brokering the arrangement.
The work continues to bring the remaining Australians, perfmanent residents and their families home, she said.
"I know how distressing the situation is for them and for their next of kin. Please be sure, we will continue to press for all of you to
cross the border in Gaza, we will continue to do what we've been doing for the last few weeks which is to engage with all that we can to ensure safe passage."

title.children: These tenants won compensation off their landlord in the High Court — and it's good news for renters everywhere

items.synopsis: We asked clinical psychologist Dr Sophie Li, from Old People's Home for Teens, for practical ways to support a teen through wellbeing challenges. These are her tips.

title.children: From anxiety to loneliness, here are five tips to help improve teen wellbeing

items.synopsis: The Canadian singer was seen at an ice hockey game on Monday night, with fans happy to see the star joking and laughing after she revealed her rare neurological illness.

title.children: Smiling Celine Dion makes rare public appearance almost a year after revealing stiff person syndrome diagnosis

image.altText: The Beatles during a photo session in Twickenham, 9 April 1969

items.synopsis: On the eve of the release of The Beatles' final ever song, created with a little help from AI technology, a new documentary sheds light on the process of making it.

items.synopsis: Israeli forces claim to have killed another Hamas commander in their second strike on Gaza's largest refugee camp in two days, as a first group of civilian evacuees from Gaza — including 20 Australians — escapes into Egypt.

image.altText: A fire burning along a road

items.synopsis: More than 60 homes have been lost in Queensland, as crews continue to battle more than 70 fires across the state.

title.children: 'We weren't able to defend': Two homes destroyed in Far North Queensland fires, as property losses top 60

image.altText: ASX 200 board

items.synopsis: The ASX is riding the wave of a Wall Street rally after the US Federal Reserve left interest rates on hold for a second straight meeting and traders bet the next move will be a cut sometime next year. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX higher amid increasing market confidence that the US Fed has finished hiking rates

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The constant numbers flashing away on my computer screen have stopped for another day, with trading on the ASX now ended. The top 200 added just shy of a per cent to end the day at 6,899 points, while the All Ordinaries put on a clean one per cent to finish at 7,095 points. Both indices are just shy of two per cent lower so far this year. Will they rally in the final two months of 2023? Here's how the top and bottom looked. Biggest gains: Sayona Mining +8.3% to $0.078 Cromwell Property +7.7% to $0.35 Pinnacle Investment +6.0% to $8.34 Centuria Capital +5.5% to $1.24 Domain Holding +2.3% to $3.60 Biggest losses: Origin Energy -6.6% to $8.47 Chalice Mining -5.1% to $1.85 Amcor -3.0% to $13.66 Santos -3.0% to $7.51 Northern Star Resources -2.6% to $11.58
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX closes up a per cent

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Federal Court has granted an interim injunction that prevents Santos from starting work on a gas pipeline in waters of Northern Australia. The order means work to lay the Barossa gas export pipeline can't start. The order comes after group Environmental Defenders Office, on behalf of Indigenous groups, urged the injunction. The indigenous group on the Tiwi Islands allege the pipeline would impact their cultural heritage. Santos says an independent anthropologist concluded there were no underwater cultural heritage places. You can read more about the issue in the article by colleague Emilia Terzon that I've posted below. The court will sit again on November 13 to determine whether to extend the injunction. Santos shares are 2.3% lower today.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Santos prevented  from starting work on gas pipeline in waters off Tiwi Islands

featuredLink.title: These Tiwi elders believe burial grounds are under threat from a gas pipeline. The company says they don't exist

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The best performer on the ASX 200 today is lithium producer Sayona Mining. The company is listed here, but most of its assets are in Canada. Today, it announced to the ASX it has found multiple high-grade lithium intercepts from a recent round of drilling at its North American Lithium (NAL) project in Quebec. Quick explainer for anyone who's not familiar with mining: When companies have a site of land they want to explore to find out what they have in the ground and how good it is, they send gigantic drills hundreds of metres — even up to a thousand — into the earth to retrieve drill or core samples. The drills churn out long poles of earth, that are then cut up into smaller pieces and assessed for their quality of whatever the mineral the company is looking for. So the team at Sayona have assessed the results of 57 drill holes (giving them 14.3km worth of sample to look at!) and they like what they see. The boss of Sayona, James Brown said in a statement to the stock exchange that the results mean a potential upgrade of what they have at their site. "Some of the intercepts from this recent drilling program are thicker and higher grade than any previously encountered, increasing confidence in NAL's mine life." I'll just add here, the company's share price is significantly lower than the start of the year - it was about $0.30 at the end of January - so it's still a long way off that figure. Today it's worth about $0.08 a share.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Lithium producer soars on drilling results

image.altText: Leanne Eatts walks past a camera wearing reflective sunglasses.

title.children: More than 160,000 Australians are expected to be diagnosed with cancer this year. But the outcomes for some will vary greatly
